body: The 2016 presidential campaign has put Americans’ gun rights “in the balance”, according to the former Texas governor Rick Perry.   Related: NRA lobbyist: 'Bernie's right' about lawsuits against gunmakers    “I don’t think this is overblown rhetoric,” Perry said in an interview outside the National Rifle Association’s annual convention in Louisville, Kentucky. “You know, in campaigns you do have some hyperbole. This is not hyperbole.” If Hillary Clinton is elected, Perry said, she will nominate a supreme court justice willing to overturn the court’s landmark 5-4 decision in District of Columbia v Heller, from 2008. In that case, the court ruled that Americans have an individual right to own firearms in the home for self-defense.  On Friday, Maya Harris, an adviser to Clinton, said the candidate believed the Heller decision was “wrongly decided”, as it undermined the ability of cities and states “to craft commonsense laws to keep their residents safe”. Supreme court justice Antonin Scalia, the author of the Heller decision, died suddenly in February. Republican leaders immediately pledged to delay the nomination of a replacement until after the 2016 election.  In endorsing presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump on Friday, NRA leaders told members: “The second amendment is on the ballot in November.” Trump once again turned the charge against Clinton. Perry, who ended his bid for the Republican nomination in September, has been a fierce critic of Trump. But he told CNN on Friday that he would be willing to be his vice-president.  “I suspect I’m going to be helping him in myriad ways,” Perry said.  Asked to comment on Sunday on what he thought about Trump’s endorsement by the NRA, Perry was lukewarm.  “Great, yeah, good, good show,” he said.  He said he was very concerned about the future of gun rights in America. If Clinton and “the anti-gun people” succeed in overturning Heller, he said, “that would jeopardize gun rights”.  Any justice nominated by Clinton, Perry added, “she will give a test to, about whether or not they’re going to be supporting gun rights”. Though it was a huge symbolic victory for gun rights advocates, the Heller decision did not radically transform gun laws in most of America. Local handgun bans were extremely rare, thanks to the political power of the NRA and other advocates.  Since Heller, courts have left other gun control laws in place, including state bans on “assault weapons”. Perry said overturning Heller would still have serious implications for gun owners. “We consider that to be the nose under the camel’s tent,” he said. “Those of us who have been in this business for a long time understand that you ratchet things one way or the other a little bit at a time.  “This is a ratcheting away from [the] second amendment right to carry freely wherever we should be able to.” Asked what he thought Clinton would realistically be able to do to restrict gun rights in her first term in the White House, Perry said: “Nothing, because she won’t be there.”   The NRA refused to issue Guardian US with accreditation for its annual convention. Reporter Lois Beckett is in Louisville and covering the event from outside.
webTitle: 'This is not hyperbole': Rick Perry says Hillary Clinton jeopardizes gun rights
